Title: The Design, Creation, and Survival of Democratic Laws (DEMOLAW)

The DEMOLAW project seeks to advance our understanding of the design, creation, and long-term survival of democratic legislation in the United States, United Kingdom, and European Union. Through the application of cutting-edge computational methods, this project aims to analyze legislative texts and answer three fundamental research questions: What conceptual dimensions capture the design of a law? Why does the design of democratic legislation vary? And how can we explain the stability or change in laws over time? 

By integrating novel conceptual perspectives on legislative design, an innovative theoretical framework on legislation creation and survival, and methodological advancements for computational analysis of legislative content, DEMOLAW will provide a comprehensive understanding of democratic lawmaking. The project's analytical framework will focus on two key dimensions: versatility and precision. 

The expected outcomes of DEMOLAW include a deeper understanding of the design and creation of democratic laws, as well as the factors contributing to their survival or change over time. This knowledge will inform policymakers, scholars, and the broader public about the intricacies of democratic lawmaking, ultimately contributing to more effective and resilient democratic institutions.
